subject: Data
title: The Bradford Hill Criteria: Proving Causation
description: A quick, practical guide to The Bradford Hill Criteria: Proving Causation.

hook.text: By 1950, data showed smokers got more lung cancer. The tobacco industry said: 'Correlation isn't causation.'

buildup.text: Austin Bradford Hill created nine criteria to evaluate whether a correlation likely reflects true causation.

discovery.text: Strength, consistency, specificity, temporality, dose-response â€” each criterion adds evidence of causation.

twist.text: Tobacco companies exploited the correlation-causation gap for decades. Hill's criteria finally closed it.

climax.text: These criteria convinced governments to act on smoking. They remain the standard for causal inference today.

punchline.text: Nine criteria ended tobacco's longest alibi.

quiz.question: Why were the Bradford Hill criteria created?
options: To systematically evaluate whether a correlation reflects causation
